body.p: The document explains how to write an effective How-to guide. The document is organized as follows:

li.xref: Why do I need a How-to?
About the Before you begin section.
Best practices for writing a How-to guide.

section.title: Introduction
section.p: How-to guides describe a set of ordered sequential steps users must complete to accomplish a specific task.
How-to guides assume that a user has basic knowledge of the product and the user knows what they want to achieve.
How-to guides are accessed by users who have experience with a product but need a specific question answered.
How-to guides can benefit new users who want to solve a problem instantly provided the How-to is well-written and states any prerequisite knowledge required to complete the task.
How-to guides have concise, easy-to-understand instructions that simplify complex actions.

How-to guides are often confused with Tutorials. Tutorials are learning-oriented, while How-to guides are task-oriented. The table below identifies the differences between Tutorials and How-to guides.

row.entry: Helps beginners or expert users learn a new feature and provide a successful learning experience
Helps an expert user accomplish a specific task or troubleshoot a particular issue.
Follows a carefully managed path, from the start to the end.
Aims for a successful result by guiding the user through a set of ordered sequential steps.
Eliminates any unexpected scenarios and provides users with a successful outcome.
Alerts the user to the possibility of unexpected scenarios, and provides guidance on how to deal with them.
Assumes that users do not have any practical knowledge, and must explicitly state any tools, file configurations, and conceptual details required for understanding.
Assumes that users have practical knowledge of tools, file configurations, and conceptual details.

title.b: Why do I need a How-to?

section.p: A How-to guide is often used to help users perform a task correctly. It can:

ul.li: Guide users to solve a problem through a set of ordered sequential steps.
Demonstrate the different capabilities of a product.
Improve the user experience, and help reduce costs by lowering the number of support requests.

section.p: Before you start working on your How-to guide:

ul.li: Identify the target audience. Who is expected to read the How-to? What prior knowledge is anticipated? This will influence the level of general and technical language of the How-to guide.
Consider the specific goal of the How-to guide. What is the How-to guide aiming to accomplish?
Determine the multiple ways through which a task can be completed. Is there one specific series of ordered sequential steps or are there multiple paths that need explaining?
Ensure that the How-to guide offers the most reliable and safest procedure to complete a task.
Take into account the different error scenarios that a user may encounter while completing a task, and provide associated solutions.

section.p: The following is an example How-to guide with essential Headings.

body.p: To put a project on GitHub you will need to create a repository (also known as a repo).
Ensure you have logged in to GitHub.

ol.li: In the top left corner, select New.
Type a short, memorable name for your repository. For example, "hello-world".
Optionally, add a short description of your repository. For example, "My first repository in GitHub."
Choose a repository visibility. You can use Public at this stage for convenience.
Select Initialize this repository with a README.

body.p: You have succssfully created your first repository, and initialized it with a README file.
For more information about repository visibility, see "About repositories."

section.p: Use this section to provide the following:

ul.li:
A clear description of the problem or the task that the user can solve or complete in this How-to. Here are some examples:
This guide explains how to comment on a pull request.
This guide explains how to create or delete a branch on GitHub.
This guide explains how to create a repository.

Optionally, explain the scenario under which this How-to guide can be used. For example, in a guide for creating a pull request from fork, inform users straightaway that if they do not have write permissions to the repository, they must fork the repository before creating a pull request.
If your main task includes multiple sub-tasks that can be used under different scenarios, you can create a table as shown below and hyperlink the different How-to guides available for the task.
Guide Scenario
Create a pull request from fork The user does not have write permission to the repo.
Create a pull request The user has write permission to the repo.

title.b: About the Before you begin section

section.p: In this section describe what your users need to know, or need to have, before they attempt the How-to. By stating the requirements up-front, you prevent your users from getting halfway through the guide and discovering that they need to go and read other documentation before they can continue.
Use this section to communicate any prerequisites for this How-to, such as:

ul.li: Environments to set up and configure.
Other guides or information to read.

section.p: For easy understanding, consider classifying the prerequisites into different categories such as software prerequisites and hardware prerequisites.
Also, include other important information here, such as known issues or bugs.
Optionally, provide any helpful cues that signal to a user that they are probably not in the right place and provide them with more suitable options. For example,
If this document does not help you resolve your issue then <provide link to a relevant article> or specify any contact support information.
The Procedure section is where you describe the steps the user needs to do to accomplish a task. Use an ordered list structure to document the How-to steps.
1. {Write the step heading here. Start with a verb.}
{Optional: Explanatory text}
{Optional: Code sample or screenshot that helps your users complete this step}
{Optional: Result}
The first element is the step itself, for example, "Enter a name for your new repository." When writing steps, keep these tips in mind:

ul.li: For step headings, start with a bare infinitive also known as plain form or base form verbs. For example, connect, set up, build.
Do not use use the -ing form of the verb because it may have multiple meanings.
Express the heading as a complete statement. For example, instead of writing, "Set up access", you should write, "Set up access to a Cloud Storage bucket."

section.p: Next, optionally provide some background information about the task so users know what they are about to do and why.
Remember to orient your users when guiding them through each step. If they need to open a particular file or dialog to complete the task, provide that information first.

Optionally, you can add a code sample or screenshot after the explanatory text, depending on the type of How-to you are writing. Screenshots are a great way to show specific parts of the screen you are referring to in a step.

If you are including code samples, make sure to add comments to your code to help learners understand what each part of the code does. Additionally, make sure your code samples work, as learners will copy and paste your code to use in their own projects.

The last, and optional, element in a step, is the result. Provide examples of sample output such as return data, a message so that the users can validate that they performed the step correctly or not. In a How-to guide for GitHub, for example, you can describe what happens after a user clicks the "Create repository" button.
Here is an example step:
Step 1. Enter a name for your new repository.
Good repository names are short and self-explanatory. Avoid repository names with three or more words.
After you click "Create repository", GitHub creates your repository and the main page for the repository is displayed.
If needed, you can add sub-steps below a primary step. Make sure to indent the sub-step one tab space over if you're using Markdown:
1. Create a new pull request.
a. Navigate to the main page of your repository.
b. Under your repository name, click **Pull requests**.
By default, all open pull requests are displayed.
If you are including code samples in your steps, make sure they are also indented correctly:

li.p: Set your Git username for your repository.
You can change the name that is associated with your Git commits using the git config command.

It's likely that during the course of explaining a multi-task process you will touch on other topics related to the current one, but not strictly required. This section is useful to provide your users with suggestions on further reading without interrupting the topic covered by the current document. An example might be setting up an email client, which requires working credentials to an active email address. The reader need not know how to install and run their own email server in order to acquire that access, although this is potentially useful. The link to documentation on running a local mail server could therefore be included in the "See also" section.

title.b: Best practices for writing a How-to guide

section.p: Consider the following when writing a How-to guide:

ol.li: Prepare your users for the unexpected, alert the user to its possibility and provide guidance on how to deal with it. For example, include callouts such as warning, caution, or note to communicate important information while completing a task.
Inform your users of all the alternatives available to complete a task. Use conditional imperatives. If you want x, do y. To achieve w, do z.
Do not provide too many links within the guide. Keep your users on a single page as much as possible. Instead provide links to additional resources at the bottom of the page.
Avoid writing guides for edge cases at the outer boundaries of your product’s capability.
